awd_titl_txt: RoL:EAGER: DESYN-C3. Bottom-up Synthetic Cells Capable of Darwinism, the Archetypal Trait of Life
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes (CLP) Program in the Division of Chemistry is funding work under the direction of Dr. Steven Benner from the Foundation for Applied Molecular Evolution to create stable artificial cells that may be used in biotechnology, especially in directed evolution. A "bottom-up" program to create artificial cells avoids the need to manage the complexity of modern living cells, a management necessary in "top-down" approaches to minimal cells. However, it requires in turn a cellular architecture simpler than the "water-oil-water" architecture of natural cells.  The research focuses on gaining control over phase separation that creates a cell structure with water inside the cell and oil outside through control over surfactants, which are small molecules that have a side that "prefers" to orient toward water and another side that prefers to orient toward the oil. These molecules determine the properties of boundaries and interfaces between the water and oil and in turn can be used in the reproducible preparation of artificial cells that are uniform in size. Such control has been sought for 20 years now and the availability of "off-the-shelf" surfactants that make control possible would boost the efforts to create an artificial cell using a bottom up approach.  The research focuses on the incorporation into the artificial cell of genetic systems that themselves can evolve, ultimately to influence the properties of the cells in a way that alters cellular fitness.

This project will create synthetic pipelines to make surfactants that give reproducible control over the physical properties of water-oil emulsions from which stable, robust and uniformly sized nanodroplets (synthetic cells) in oil can be prepared. We will develop surfactants that do not denature the enzymes, genes, and other biologics that reside within the cells. The artificial cell architecture involves just two phases, an external lipid phase and internal water phase. Systems that allow the delivery of water and other small molecules to the cell will be integrated in the synthetic cells.  The research will then aim to create a mechanism by which the synthetic cells can change their external traits in response to molecular evolution processes that takes plan in the cell.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Biotechnology, for all its slick, cutting-edge innovation, borrows most from nature. Look at cells, for example. Within them, encapsulation of biological reactions occurs inherently. Biotechnology nowadays relies on encapsulation for a variety of applications. Biological reactions can be encapsulated in water-in-oil droplets and are produced using a fluid not miscible with water (hydrophobic) and a surfactant, which facilitates the formation of water droplets surrounded by the hydrophobic fluid. Enzymes, the workhorses of biotechnology have both hydrophobic and hydrophilic (water-loving) parts. The contact of a hydrophobic fluid or the hydrophobic part of a surfactant can potentially interact with the hydrophobic part of the enzyme and denature it, leaving it inactive.

Fluorinated molecules provide a third class of molecules, which are not miscible with water but also do not mix with the hydrophobic portions of the enzymes. Making them inert to biological systems. Nevertheless, the fluorine atom is heavier than oxygen and on average most compounds containing fluorine will be heavier than their counterparts. This higher density has an immediate consequence: the water droplets would float on top of the fluid. This fact makes the manipulation of the droplets difficult and expose the droplets to the fluid/air interface.

We set out to look for a fluorinated fluid useful for encapsulation that would have a density like that of water. The greater atomic mass of fluorine can be partly offset by the larger volumes of CF2 and CF3 (carbon-fluorine) groups relative to CH2 and CH3 (carbon-hydrogen), both less dense than water. Therefore, we reasoned that fluorous fluids having a density of water could be obtained by balancing their fluorinated components with alkane (CH2 and CH3) components, and made a polymer that has both CH3 and CF3 groups. Synthetic polymers are strings of repeating units and are produced in a wide range of lengths. Synthetic polymers are characterized not only by the chemical structure of their repeating units but also by describing the lengths of the different chains that make up the mixture. The polymer lengths are separated, counted and tallied in a graph called molecular weight distribution. The polymer we prepared has two distinctive groups of molecules of different sizes. We found that we could separate these two distinctive fractions of the polymer mixture by distillation. One of these fractions (lower molecular weight) can dissolve the fluorinated surfactants needed for the system.

To verify the solubility of the surfactants in the fluorinated fluid we prepared solutions up to 4% of the surfactant dissolved in the low molecular weight fraction of the fluorinated fluid then we looked for the signals that arise from the nuclear magnetic resonance of the fluorine atoms and verified the presence of the surfactant in the dissolved material. The formation of the water-in-oil emulsions can be achieved using microfluidic devices which have channels between 10 to 50 micrometers. Alternatively, the emulsions can be prepared very quickly by shaking the two phases.

The stability of the droplets formed depends on many factors. Besides the presence of a surfactant, the presence of higher molecular weight species contributes to the stability of the emulsion formed. Here, a delicate balance needs to be found since high viscosity is not well-tolerated in microfluidic devices. Properties like viscosity are extremely sensitive to the presence of high molecular weight species. These two polymer samples appear to have a very similar profile in molecular weight distribution. However, their densities are 61 cSt and 108 cSt. 

The encapsulation of millions of different reactions in a very small volume opens up possibilities which otherwise would have been undoable. For example, an approach that uses encapsulation, resembling what happens in cells, is an approach called directed evolution. In directed evolution a gene the protein encoded by it are isolated and a protein variant can be evolved to a desired trait. A major challenge in this kind of experiment is the vast number of possible variants that can be explored. Each amino acid position in a protein can have 20 possible changes. If you want to explore 4 changes then you will have 20x20x20x20 = 160,000 possibilities. If you want to explore 6 changes then there are 64 million possibilities. The encapsulation of each different reaction in a separate droplet makes these kind of projects feasible.
